grounding: Neutron captures produce the vast majority of abundances of elements heavier than iron in the Universe. Beyond the classical slow (s) and rapid (r) processes, there is observational evidence for neutron-capture processes that operate at neutron densities in between, at different distances from the valley of Î² stability. Here, we review the main properties of the s process within the general context of neutron-capture processes and the nuclear physics input required to investigate it. We describe massive stars and asymptotic giant branch stars as the s-process astrophysical sites and discuss the related physical uncertainties. We also present current observational evidence for the s process and beyond, which ranges from stellar spectroscopic observations to laboratory analysis of meteorites.
generated_text: This study delves into the s-process (slow neutron capture process) of nucleosynthesis, a fundamental mechanism responsible for the creation of approximately half of the atomic nuclei heavier than iron in the universe. By examining the intricate nuclear reactions and neutron captures occurring within Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) stars and massive stars, we aim to elucidate the conditions and environments conducive to the s-process. Furthermore, this research explores the implications of stellar spectroscopy and meteoritic anomalies in understanding the distribution and abundance of s-process elements. Our findings contribute to a deeper comprehension of stellar evolution, nucleosynthesis, and the chemical evolution of the galaxy, offering insights into the cosmic origins of heavy elements beyond the s-process.
